concept.title: Alarm and Event List

othermeta.name: shortdesc
othermeta.content: Complete listing of alarms and events with descriptions, severity levels, and recommended actions.

othermeta.name: usecase
othermeta.content: provide reference for operators and technicians to identify and respond to alarms

conbody.p:
All alarms and events are always stored in the event log. Depending on the alarm it can also be stored in the alarm stack and affect the common alarm. There are three different types of alarms:
Event only: Saved only in the event log. Does not affect the common alarm.
Alarm only: Saved in the event log and the alarm stack. Does not affect the common alarm.
Alarm and common alarm: Saved in the event log and the alarm stack. Affects the common alarm.
The alarm text is only displayed in English even if another system language is used.

entry.p: The main processor unit has been reset. Occurs after a reset or a start-up from a completely turned off state.
The system could not be initialized after a start-up. It is not possible to start the system.
The charger turns off due to auto off parameter.
The AC circuit of the redundant PSU is not working.
The DC circuit of the redundant PSU is not working.
At least one supply (+5 V, +15 V, -15 V) is out of tolerance (±0.3 for 5 V respective ±1.5 for 15 V).
At least one task of the MPU needs too much time.
The MPU code memory CRC is incorrect. It is not possible to turn on the system.
The FPU code memory CRC is incorrect. It is not possible to turn on the system.
The CL code memory CRC is incorrect. It is not possible to turn on the system.
Not possible to read parameter data from the EEPROM.
Not possible to save parameter data to the EEPROM.
Rectifier mains input breaker is open.
The charger is not synchronous to mains voltage.
At least one of the 3 mains phases are missing.
The mains phase rotation is wrong.
Mains frequency is out of tolerance.
Mains voltage is out of tolerance.
The difference between the highest and lowest mains phase voltage is greater than 25% and this condition persists for 500 ms.
The DC voltage is below the low V DC warning level.
The DC voltage is below the low V DC shutdown level.
The DC voltage is above the high V DC warning level.
The DC voltage is above the high2 V DC shutdown level.
The Vaux voltage (after diode) is below low V DC warning level.
The Vaux voltage (after diode) is below low V DC shutdown level.
The Vaux voltage (after diode) is above high V DC warning level.
The Vaux voltage (after diode) is above high V DC shutdown level.
The current limiter for the total DC current is active for more than 5 seconds.
The rectifier fuse F026 or F027 has blown.
The actual DC voltage ±3% outside the reference DC voltage for more than 5 seconds.

This alarm is active if either:
No DC feedback signal, or
If no current limiter active and charger is on and DC set point voltage - actual DC voltage is above 75% of nominal output voltage.
Load sharing error between 0° and 30° rectifier module. The two currents differ more than ±7.5% .
The battery current limit is active for more than 5 seconds.
Battery current is more than +5% over limit threshold for at least 2 minutes. The charger is set to nominal DC voltage and the current limiter is off. Battery current sensor must be replaced.
The battery temperature is too high.
The temperature sensor is inoperable because the temperature is outside of the defined range -35 °C – +60 °C (-31 °F – +140 °F). The V DC temperature compensation turns off.
Half the battery voltage is outside the window of ±1.5%. A battery cell is defective.
The output of the units are not connected (only in redundant systems).
No primary unit is defined (only in redundant systems).
Load sharing differs more than ±10% for more than 30 seconds (only in redundant systems).
A battery test is active in the other unit (only in redundant systems).
The charger 0° temperature is above the warning level (>90 °C (194 °F) or >100 °C (212 °F) depending on SDC type).
The charger 0° temperature is above the shutdown level (>100 °C (212 °F) or >110 °C (230 °F) depending on SDC type).
The charger 30° temperature is above the warning level (>90 °C (194 °F) or >100 °C (212 °F) depending on SDC type).
The charger 30° temperature is above the shutdown level (>100 °C (212 °F) or >110 °C (230 °F) depending on SDC type).
The transformer temperature is too high. After 10 minutes the charger switches off.
The transformer has shutdown because of overheating.
The choke temperature is too high. After 10 minutes the charger switches off.
The choke has shutdown because of overheating.
Temperature signal switch in diode is off.
Fan 1 is rotating too slowly (fan pulse signal < 20 Hz).
Fan 2 is rotating too slowly (fan pulse signal < 20 Hz).
Fan 3 is rotating too slowly (fan pulse signal < 20 Hz).
Fan 4 is rotating too slowly (fan pulse signal < 20 Hz).
Fan 5 is rotating too slowly (fan pulse signal < 20 Hz).
Fan 6 is rotating too slowly (fan pulse signal < 20 Hz).
Fan 7 is rotating too slowly (fan pulse signal < 20 Hz).
Fan 8 is rotating too slowly (fan pulse signal < 20 Hz).
Option 5 input open if set as float reduce.
Option 6 input open if set as battery charge.
Option 7 input open if set as external synch.
Option 8 input open if set as DC bus connect.
Boost and initial charge is blocked. It is not possible to enter boost or initial charge manually or automatically.
The charger is turned off because of VLU alert.
The system's main controller board is starting up.
The system is in float charge mode.
The system is in boost charge mode.
The system is in initial charge mode.
The system is in battery operation.
The advanced battery monitoring (ABM) test is running.
The battery capacity test is running.
The internal buzzer is linked to a programmable relay.
After 3 consecutive high DC shutdowns the system is locked and must be rested for restart.
Successful login to the level 1 (settings stack).
Successful login to the level 2 (configuration stack).
A user changed a parameter in level 0 (user stack).
A user changed a parameter in level 1 (settings stack).
A user changed a parameter in level 2 (configuration stack).
Loss of communication between the controller and the NMC for 120 seconds or longer.
External off over the external connection board (A025) was activated.
The master mode password has been changed.
The edit level 1 (settings stack) password has been changed.
The edit level 2 (configuration stack) password has been changed.
The DC voltage have been above the set high1 V DC shutdown level for a set time. The high1 V DC level and time can be configured for the load.
The main processor unit has been reset. Occurs after a reset or a start-up from a completely turned off state.
The system could not be initialized after a start-up. It is not possible to start the system.
The charger control of the thyristors is turned off due to supply or serial peripheral interface (SPI) communication failure.
The inverter control of the insulated-gate bipolar transistor (IGBT) turned off due to supply failure.
One of the controller supplies (+5V, +12V, -12V, +20V) is almost out of range.
At least one of the controller supplies (+5V, +12V, -12V, +20V) is out of range and the system output is blocked.
6: PSU1 AC or DC not working
At least one of the standard redundant supplies (AC or DC) is not working.
AC PSU supply for the extended power module block 3 and 4 is not working.
DC PSU supply for the extended power module block 3 and 4 not working.
At least one task of the MPU needs too much time.
MPU alive signal to the masterlogic is off.
FPU alive signal to the masterlogic is off.
The MPU code memory CRC is incorrect. It is not possible to turn on the system.
The FPU code memory CRC is incorrect. It is not possible to turn on the system.
The ML code memory CRC is incorrect. It is not possible to turn on the system.
The CL code memory CRC is incorrect. It is not possible to turn on the system.
Not possible to read parameter data from the EEPROM.
Not possible to save parameter data to the EEPROM.
The system is locked in bypass operation by the independent system surveillance (ISS) control.
The other unit in a redundant system is locked in bypass operation by the ISS control (only in redundant systems).
ISS control on the masterlogic is not ready.
The system is locked in bypass operation by the Independent Static Bypass Switch (ISBS).
The ISBS cannot switch to bypass because it could not switch on the static switch EN.
Rectifier mains input breaker is open.
The rectifier is not synchronous to mains voltage.
Mains voltage (average) is out of tolerance.
Mains frequency is out of tolerance.
At least one of the 3 mains phases are missing. The highest voltage is >20% of nominal voltage.
The mains phase rotation is wrong.
The DC voltage is below the low V DC warning level.
The DC voltage is below the low V DC shutdown level.
The DC voltage is above the high V DC warning level.
The DC voltage is above the high V DC shutdown level.
High DC voltage detected by PSU.
DC voltage above defined limit. The rectifier is temporary turned off. The rectifier turns on without soft ramp when the voltage is below the limit.
External VLU system alert is active, if DC voltage over defined threshold on the VLU system. Rectifier is turned off.
The rectifier output breaker is open.
The current limiter for the total DC current is active for more than 5 seconds.
The rectifier fuse has blown F026 or F027 blown.
The actual DC voltage +/- 5% outside the reference DC voltage for more than 5 seconds.

This alarm is active if either:
The 47: UI-deviation warning alarm was active for >3 minutes and the battery current >10% of limit value, or
The DC voltage <25% of reference value with the battery current limit off.
The battery breaker is open. Depending on the system configuration this indication might not be used or wired to another breaker.
The battery current limit is active for more than 5 seconds.
Battery current is more than +5% over limit threshold for at least 2 minutes. The charger is set to nominal DC voltage and the current limiter is off. Battery current sensor must be replaced.
The battery temperature is too high.
The temperature sensor is inoperable because the temperature is outside of the defined range -35°C – +60°C (-31°F – 140°F). The V DC temperature compensation turns off.
The battery voltage is below the warning level.
The battery voltage is below the defect level.
The external battery breaker is open.
The inverter input breaker is open.
The inverter is not synchronized to the bypass.
The inverter voltage is 15% below the internal reference. The inverter turns off and the system switches to bypass if possible, or it will turn off.
The inverter fuse F021 has blown. The inverter turns off and the system switches to bypass if possible, or it will turn off.
The output voltage is above the tolerance level.
The output voltage (average) is out of tolerance. The system switches to bypass if possible, or it switches off after defined time (default 5 seconds).
The output voltage (fast) is out of tolerance.
The output frequency is out of tolerance. The system switches to bypass if possible, or it switches off after defined time (default 5 seconds).
The load on the inverter output has reached more than 100% of the nominal value. The system is overloaded.
The current is above the calibrated load profile (>150%) or the overcurrent protection is active on at least one of the inverter modules.
Current limiter indicated from one or more power module on Block1 (Standard Block).
Current limiter indicated from one or more power module on Block2.
Current limiter indicated from one or more power module on Block3.
Current limiter indicated from one or more power module on Block4.
At least one of the fans is rotating too slowly.
The CB03 current is below the warning level.
The CB03 current is below the shutdown level. The inverter turns off and the system switches to bypass if possible, or it will turn off.
The bypass input breaker is open.
The bypass voltage (average) is out of tolerance.
The bypass voltage (fast) is out of tolerance.
The bypass frequency is out of tolerance.
The manual bypass switch is in the Test or Bypass position.
91: Bypass freq sync out of tol
The bypass mains frequency is out of tolerance. Only asynchronous switch to bypass is possible.
The static switch EN is inoperable. It is not possible to switch to bypass operation.
The bypass mains phase rotation is wrong.
At least of the 3 phases is missing and the highest voltage is > 20% of nominal voltage.
Output of system1 and system2 is not connected, or one of the systems is in standby or disconnected from power supply (only in redundant systems).
At least one parallel cable is not connected (only in redundant systems).
All parallel cables are disconnected, or other systems are disconnected from power supply (only in redundant systems).
The master system turns off automatically. This indicates that the system turned off because the current limiter was active (only in redundant systems).
The charger 0° temperature is above the warning level (>90°C).
The rectifier 0° temperature is above the shutdown level (>100°C). The rectifier turns off and the system switches to battery or bypass operation if possible, or it switches off.
The charger 30° temperature is above the warning level (>90°C).
The charger 30° temperature is above the shutdown level (>100°C). The rectifier turns off and the system switches to battery or bypass operation if possible, or it switches off.
The rectifier transformer or choke temperature is too high. After 10 minutes the rectifier turns off and the system switches to battery or bypass operation if possible, or it switches off.
The rectifier has shutdown because of overheating.
The inverter transformer or choke temperature is too high. After 10 minutes the inverter turns off and the system switches to bypass operation if possible, or it switches off.
The inverter has shutdown because of overheating.
The inverter static switch EA temperature is above the warning level (>90°C).
The inverter static switch EA temperature is above the shutdown level (>100°C). The system switches to bypass operation if possible, or it switches off.
The bypass static switch EN temperature is above the warning level (>90°C).

The bypass static switch EN temperature is above the shutdown level (>100°C). It is not possible to switch to bypass operation from the front panel. In bypass operation the system tries to switch back to normal or battery operation if possible, if not it remains in bypass operation.
The inverter power module (PM1-L1) temperature is above the warning level (>90°C).
The inverter power module (PM1-L1) temperature is above the shutdown level (>100°C). The inverter turns off and the system switches to bypass operation if possible, or it switches off.
The inverter power module (PM1-L2) temperature is above the warning level (>90°C).
The inverter power module (PM1-L2) temperature is above the shutdown level (>100°C). The inverter turns off and the system switches to bypass operation if possible, or it switches off.
The inverter power module (PM1-L3) temperature is above the warning level (>90°C).
The inverter power module (PM1-L3) temperature is above the shutdown level (>100°C). The inverter turns off and the system switches to bypass operation if possible, or it switches off.
The inverter power module (PM2-L1) temperature is above the warning level (>90°C).
The inverter power module (PM2-L1) temperature is above the shutdown level (>100°C). The inverter turns off and the system switches to bypass operation if possible, or it switches off.
The inverter power module (PM2-L2) temperature is above the warning level (>90°C).
The inverter power module (PM2-L2) temperature is above the shutdown level (>100°C). The inverter turns off and the system switches to bypass operation if possible, or it switches off.
The inverter power module (PM2-L3) temperature is above the warning level (>90°C).
The inverter power module (PM2-L3) temperature is above the shutdown level (>100°C). The inverter turns off and the system switches to bypass operation if possible, or it switches off.
The inverter power module (PM3-L1) temperature is above the warning level (>90°C).
The inverter power module (PM3-L1) temperature is above the shutdown level (>100°C). The inverter turns off and the system switches to bypass operation if possible, or it switches off.
The inverter power module (PM3-L2) temperature is above the warning level (>90°C).
The inverter power module (PM3-L2) temperature is above the shutdown level (>100°C). The inverter turns off and the system switches to bypass operation if possible, or it switches off.
The inverter power module (PM3-L3) temperature is above the warning level (>90°C).
The inverter power module (PM3-L3) temperature is above the shutdown level (>100°C). The inverter turns off and the system switches to bypass operation if possible, or it switches off.
The inverter power module (PM4-L1) temperature is above the warning level (>90°C).
The inverter power module (PM4-L1) temperature is above the shutdown level (>100°C). The inverter turns off and the system switches to bypass operation if possible, or it switches off.
The inverter power module (PM4-L2) temperature is above the warning level (>90°C).
The inverter power module (PM4-L2) temperature is above the shutdown level (>100°C). The inverter turns off and the system switches to bypass operation if possible, or it switches off.
The inverter power module (PM4-L3) temperature is above the warning level (>90°C).
The inverter power module (PM4-L3) temperature is above the shutdown level (>100°C). The inverter turns off and the system switches to bypass operation if possible, or it switches off.
The advanced battery monitoring (ABM) test is running.
The battery capacity test is running.
The float reduce function is active.
The charger boost mode is blocked.
The charger boost mode is active.
The system is locked in bypass operation, because the inverter has changed more than 8 times to bypass and back in two minutes.
The system is locked in bypass operation. It will be released with dedicated input signal.
157: Charger off due to VLU alert
The charger is turned off and locked because of VLU alert.
The system is in charge only mode. The signal must be used to consider the status of the DC UPS system supplying the inverter system.
The system is in normal operation.
The system is in battery operation.
The system is in bypass operation, because the system detected a fault and reacted accordingly.
The system is in economy operation.
The system is in hot standby mode.
The system is in bypass operation, changed by the user from the display.
The system was switched off with a signal through the external connection board.
Successful login to the level 1 (settings stack).
Successful login to the level 2 (configuration stack).
A user changed a parameter in level 0 (user stack).
A user changed a parameter in level 1 (settings stack).
A user changed a parameter in level 2 (configuration stack).
Loss of communication between the controller and the NMC for 120 seconds or longer.
The edit level 1 (settings stack) password has been changed.
The edit level 2 (configuration stack) password has been changed.
The master mode password has been changed.
